articles.title: Unlocking the Secrets of Beer Foam Stability
articles.summary: A seven-year study by researchers at ETH Zurich, led by Professor Jan Vermant, has revealed the scientific principles behind why some beers maintain a stable foam longer than others. Published in Physics of Fluids, the research analyzed Belgian ales such as Tripel, Dubbel, and Singel, finding that Tripel beers have the most durable foam due to unique physical forces, while Singel beers have the least stable foam because of milder fermentation and lower alcohol content. The team also examined lagers from Swiss breweries, noting that while some can match the foam stability of ales, the underlying mechanisms differ. Previously, it was thought that protein-rich layers alone stabilized foam, but this study shows that factors like surface viscoelasticity and Marangoni stresses play key roles. For instance, in lagers, higher protein levels increase surface stiffness, aiding foam longevity, whereas in Tripel beers, Marangoni stresses—caused by surface tension variations—help maintain foam. This research not only advances our understanding of fluid dynamics but also provides practical insights for brewers to enhance beer quality through controlled brewing processes.

articles.title: Drag Race UK Winner's Prize Money Plans
articles.summary: Bones emerged as the winner of RuPaul's Drag Race UK series seven, securing a £25,000 cash prize after a intense lip-sync battle against Elle Vosque. In an interview with BBC Newsbeat, Bones expressed overwhelming happiness and described the win as the cherry on top of her journey. She revealed a pact with fellow finalist Elle from west Belfast to take each other on a holiday if either won, with potential destinations including Europe, the Caribbean, or a cruise. Originally from Stalybridge, Greater Manchester, Bones has been involved in drag for seven years and is now a prominent figure in London's Soho drag scene. She plans to use the prize money to enhance her drag performances, noting that drag is an expensive art form requiring significant investment in costumes and creativity. Additionally, Bones commented on the growing popularity and saturation of drag, emphasizing that queens must now proactively create opportunities for themselves. This marks the second year the UK edition has offered a cash prize since its 2019 launch, reflecting the show's evolving impact on the drag community.

articles.title: Tax Changes and Their Impact on Small Businesses
articles.summary: The article discusses the effects of recent business rates changes announced in the UK Budget, focusing on Phil Thorley, who runs a pub chain in south east England. His costs are set to rise by £62,000 annually due to increases in business rates for 17 of his 18 pubs. Business rates are taxes based on the rental value of commercial properties, and the government, through Chancellor Rachel Reeves, had promised lower taxes for retail, leisure, and hospitality sectors by shifting the burden to high-value properties like those used by online giants. However, the implementation has led to higher rateable values for many firms, combined with the phasing out of a 40% Covid-era discount. Analysis by Ryan, a tax advisory firm, indicates average increases of 42% for small shops, 45% for restaurants, and 66% for pubs. Thorley argues that this, along with previous hikes in employer national insurance and the minimum wage, puts immense pressure on his business, potentially reducing employment and investment. The government claims it is saving typical pubs £4,800 yearly, but the net result for many is significant cost hikes, raising concerns about the survival of small businesses.

articles.title: Tax Exemption for State Pension-Only Recipients
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves has confirmed that individuals whose sole income is from the state pension will not be required to pay income tax before 2030. This decision comes as the state pension amount is projected to exceed the income tax threshold of £12,570 by April 2027, due to planned increases and frozen tax thresholds. Currently, the state pension for those under the new system is £12,547.60, just below this limit. The policy aims to prevent administrative burdens for vulnerable pensioners, as tax collection typically involves the Simple Assessment process where HMRC calculates and issues tax demands. However, this move raises concerns about fairness and complexity, as about three-quarters of pensioners already pay tax because they have additional income from private pensions or other sources. Experts, including former pensions minister Steve Webb, highlight that it could lead to unequal treatment, favoring those on the new state pension over workers with similar incomes or pensioners on the old system. The Conservatives had previously made a similar pledge, indicating cross-party attention to pensioner welfare, but critics argue it may complicate the tax system and create winners and losers.

articles.title: Olivia Dean's Fight Against High Ticket Resale Prices
articles.summary: Olivia Dean, a rising music star, has publicly criticized Ticketmaster and AXS for what she calls an 'exploitative' and unequal ticketing system. After tickets for her North American tour were resold at prices over 14 times the original face value, reaching above $1,000, Dean wrote an open letter denouncing the practice as 'disgusting' and 'vile.' In response, Ticketmaster announced it would cap future resale rates for her tour and refund fans for any markups paid on their platform. The CEO of Live Nation Entertainment, Ticketmaster's parent company, expressed agreement with Dean's goal of keeping live music accessible. Dean emphasized on Instagram that the secondary ticket market is unregulated and urged the industry to allow artists to cap resale at face value. This issue is part of a broader movement, as the UK government plans to outlaw excessive ticket resale prices following appeals from major artists like Coldplay and Dua Lipa. Dean's actions highlight the power of artists in advocating for fan rights and fair pricing in the entertainment industry.

articles.title: Unveiling Molecular Dynamics with X-Ray Imaging and Lasers
articles.summary: Researchers have advanced our understanding of molecular behavior under intense laser fields by using X-ray diffraction to create movies of Buckminsterfullerene (C60) disintegration. This football-shaped molecule, composed of 60 carbon atoms, was exposed to powerful infrared lasers at the Linac Coherent Light Source. By analyzing X-ray patterns, scientists measured parameters like radius and Guinier amplitude to track expansion and fragmentation. At low laser intensity, the molecule expands before fragmenting, while at high intensity, rapid electron loss causes immediate breakdown. The study involved international collaboration and combined experimental data with theoretical models, though discrepancies highlighted the need for improved theories. This work is crucial for guiding chemical reactions with light and exploring quantum processes in complex molecules.
